awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of age of acquisition in emerging sign languages
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the basic functions of grammar in a language is to mark who does what to whom, which is referred to as argument ordering. This is critical information for users of the language to communicate, but previous research has not identified where such grammatical marking of arguments comes from in language. Children exposed to an established language acquire the language specific grammar at a young age, but what happens when children are not exposed to a language with this grammar? Around 95% of deaf children around the world are born into hearing families who do not sign. Age of first exposure to language for these individuals varies widely and often occurs in educational settings, if at all. When deaf children are gathered without access to a sign language, the communication system they develop will become a new sign language over generations of users. This doctoral dissertation project examines the effects of age of exposure and age of language on the development of argument structure by looking at the development of word order as grammatical marking in three sign languages of various ages. Two of the three sign languages have not been documented previously and are less than 40 years old. Along with training of a doctoral student, this project will engage underrepresented individuals in scientific research and raise public awareness about emerging sign languages.

The three studies use video recordings of sign language users describing pictures. The stimuli are carefully controlled to include different event types and both animate and inanimate arguments. Recordings are annotated for word order and any other potential grammatical devices used by the signers. Statistical analyses are used to determine how age of language exposure impacts the use of these grammatical devices in each of the three languages. Furthermore, differences between groups in the studies of this dissertation highlight interacting effects of both age of the emerging language and the age at which children enter the signing community on argument ordering. By looking at these factors in these unique situations, this project adds to the scientific understanding of the origins of argument ordering in language and the role of early access to language in that process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Deaf children around the world encounter highly variable language input. Most deaf babies (~95%) are born to hearing parents who do not sign. Many deaf children first encounter sign language when they enter a school program that uses the national sign language. However, in some places in the world the school systems have not integrated the sign languages of the deaf community. Given all this variation, the dissertation examined how deaf children develop ways to signal who is the doer or subject in a sentence and who is the patient or object in a sentence in three different contexts.  

Specifically, data was gathered in two countries where deaf children experience different language input. In Fiji, deaf children attend a deaf school where Fiji Sign Language is the language of instruction. Data was gathered during a 17 day fieldwork visit to Fiji from 13 children and 23 adults, resulting in 150 video sessions. Some deaf  children in Vanuatu briefly attended this school. For the last five years, these children and other deaf children in Vanuatu have been mainstreamed at a large hearing school. Over three years video recordings of the six deaf children signing were made once a year in Vanuatu. 

                  We found that the deaf children and adults in Fiji use both  word order in the sentence and spatial marking to show who did what to whom. For deaf children in Vanuatu, they did not adopt these same strategies from their brief contact with Fiji Sign Language. Instead, over time, as they continue to communicate with each other, they begin to make use more spatial strategies that have been seen in many sign languages such as use of classifiers and spatial agreement on verbs.

                  By looking at these two contexts where deaf children have different exposure to structured language input, we have been able to show that deaf children in communication with each other demonstrate new ways of showing who did what to whom. These strategies  may become the grammar in their sign language. This unique context allows us to see how grammar develops in a new language. By looking at the same children in Vanuatu multiple times over the three years, we are able to examine how language is created both by an individual child and by a community.  This helps us to understand the impact of variable language input in the language development of deaf children and may in the future inform the creation of better services and tools for promoting language development in deaf children.
